message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Option (B) is correct as increasing heart rate decreases the relative amount of time spent during diastole, which is when the coronary arteries are perfused. Option (A) is false as increasing heart rate decreases the amount of time spent during each cardiac cycle. Option (C) is false as perfusion of the myocardium primarily takes place during diastole. Option (D) is false as perfusion of the myocardium is greater during diastole than systole.

We refer to physiology articles on the cardiovascular system for help. As the heart rate increases, the cardiac cycle shortens and the relative amount of time spent during diastole decreases. This can lead to decreased perfusion of the myocardium and cause symptoms such as chest tightness. Option A is incorrect as increasing heart rate shortens the time spent during each cardiac cycle. Option C is incorrect as perfusion of the myocardium primarily takes place during diastole. Option D is incorrect as perfusion is not equal throughout the cardiac cycle.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Option B is the correct statement. As heart rate increases, the amount of time spent in diastole decreases, which can lead to decreased coronary artery perfusion and chest pain, especially in patients with coronary artery disease. Option A is false, as increasing heart rate decreases the amount of time spent in each cardiac cycle. Option C is false, as perfusion of the myocardium takes place primarily during diastole. Option D is false, as perfusion of the myocardium is greater during diastole compared to systole.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Option B is correct because as heart rate increases, diastole, which is the resting or filling phase of the cardiac cycle, becomes shorter relative to the systole, which is the contracting phase, leading to a decreased amount of time spent in diastole. This can result in decreased myocardial perfusion, causing chest tightness or angina. Option A is false because increasing heart rate decreases the amount of time spent in each cardiac cycle. Option C is false because perfusion of the myocardium primarily takes place during diastole when the coronary arteries are filled with blood. Option D is false because perfusion of the myocardium is not equal throughout the cardiac cycle, with the majority of perfusion occurring during diastole.

We refer to physiology textbooks for help. Option (B) is correct because as the heart rate increases, the duration of diastole decreases relative to systole, which can result in decreased blood flow to the coronary arteries and ischemia in patients with coronary artery disease. Option (A) is incorrect because increasing heart rate decreases duration of each cardiac cycle. Option (C) is incorrect because perfusion of the myocardium takes place primarily during diastole, when the coronary arteries are able to fill with blood. Option (D) is incorrect because perfusion of the myocardium is not equal throughout the cardiac cycle, but rather occurs primarily during diastole.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Option (B) is the correct answer. As the heart rate increases, the time spent during diastole decreases, which can cause inadequate perfusion to the myocardium and lead to chest pain. Option (A) is false, as increasing the heart rate decreases the amount of time spent during each cardiac cycle. Option (C) is false, as perfusion of the myocardium takes place mainly during diastole. Option (D) is false, as perfusion of the myocardium is more efficient during diastole compared to systole.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. During an increased heart rate, the relative amount of time spent during diastole decreases, which may cause a decrease in coronary artery perfusion, leading to chest tightness. Option A is incorrect because increasing heart rate decreases the amount of time spent during each cardiac cycle. Option C is incorrect because perfusion of the myocardium primarily takes place during diastole due to greater coronary artery perfusion pressure. Option D is incorrect because perfusion during diastole is greater than during systole.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Option B is correct because increasing the heart rate decreases the duration of diastole, the phase where the heart is relaxed and fills with blood. This can lead to decreased myocardial perfusion, which may cause chest tightness during exercise. Option A is incorrect because increasing the heart rate decreases the duration of each cardiac cycle. Option C is incorrect because myocardial perfusion takes place primarily during diastole, not systole. Option D is incorrect because perfusion is not equal throughout the cardiac cycle, but primarily occurs during diastole.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. When heart rate increases, the relative amount of time spent during diastole decreases. The diastolic phase is the time during which the coronary arteries bring blood to the myocardium, so decreasing the amount of time spent during diastole can result in reduced perfusion to the myocardium, which can cause the patient’s symptoms. Option A is false because a higher heart rate shortens the amount of time spent during each cardiac cycle. Option C is false because perfusion of the myocardium takes place primarily during diastole. Option D is false because perfusion of the myocardium is greater during diastole than systole.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Increasing the heart rate decreases the relative amount of time spent during diastole, because systole takes up a larger percentage of the cardiac cycle. Perfusion of the myocardium does not take place primarily during systole, but rather throughout the cardiac cycle. Option A is incorrect because increasing the heart rate actually decreases the amount of time spent during each cardiac cycle.
